options: A proposition that is always true
A statement containing variables that becomes a proposition when variables are given values
questions.explanation: A predicate is a statement template with variables (like P(x) = "x is prime"). It becomes a proposition when specific values are substituted.

questions.prompt: The statement ∀x P(x) is true if P(x) is true for every element in the domain.
questions.explanation: The universal quantifier ∀ means "for all." ∀x P(x) is true when P(x) holds for every x in the domain.

options: P(x) is true for all x
P(x) is true for at least one x
P(x) is false for all x
P(x) is true for exactly one x
questions.explanation: The existential quantifier ∃ means "there exists." ∃x P(x) is true when P(x) holds for at least one x in the domain.

questions.prompt: What is the negation of ∀x P(x)?
questions.explanation: The negation of "for all x, P(x)" is "there exists x such that NOT P(x)." ¬∀x P(x) ≡ ∃x ¬P(x).
Negating "there exists x with P(x)" gives "for all x, NOT P(x)." ¬∃x P(x) ≡ ∀x ¬P(x).

questions.prompt: How would you translate "All dogs bark" into predicate logic? (D(x) = "x is a dog", B(x) = "x barks")
questions.explanation: "All dogs bark" means: for everything, IF it's a dog THEN it barks. Use → with ∀ for "all A are B."

questions.prompt: How would you translate "Some birds can swim"? (B(x) = "x is a bird", S(x) = "x can swim")
questions.explanation: "Some birds can swim" means: there exists something that IS a bird AND can swim. Use ∧ with ∃ for "some A are B."

questions.prompt: The statements ∀x ∃y P(x, y) and ∃y ∀x P(x, y) always have the same truth value.
questions.explanation: Order matters! ∀x ∃y means "for each x, some y exists (possibly different for each x)." ∃y ∀x means "one y works for all x." These are different.

questions.prompt: Let the domain be real numbers. Which statement is TRUE?
questions.explanation: "For every x, there exists a y greater than x" is true (just take y = x + 1). "There exists a y greater than all x" is false (no largest real number).

questions.prompt: The uniqueness quantifier ∃! x P(x) means "there exists exactly ____ x such that P(x)."
questions.explanation: ∃! (exists unique) means there is exactly one element satisfying the property.

questions.prompt: What is the negation of ∀x (P(x) → Q(x))?
The statements ∀x P(x) ∧ ∀x Q(x) and ∀x (P(x) ∧ Q(x)) are logically equivalent.
questions.explanation: Universal quantifiers distribute over conjunction. "Everything has P and everything has Q" ≡ "Everything has both P and Q."

questions.prompt: Which is the correct expansion of ∃!x P(x)?
questions.explanation: ∃!x P(x) means "exists x with P(x), and any y with P(y) must equal x." Uniqueness combines existence with the condition that anything else satisfying P is the same element.

questions.prompt: What does ∀x ∃y ∀z P(x, y, z) assert?
options: For all x, y, z: P(x, y, z)
For each x, there is a y that works for all z
There is some x such that for all y and z, P holds
For each pair (x, z), there is a y such that P holds
questions.explanation: Reading left to right: for each x, we can find a y (depending on x) such that for all z, P(x, y, z) is true.

questions.prompt: ∃x (P(x) ∧ Q(x)) logically implies (∃x P(x)) ∧ (∃x Q(x)), but not vice versa.
questions.explanation: If some x satisfies both P and Q, then certainly something satisfies P and something satisfies Q. But having witnesses for P and Q separately doesn't mean the SAME witness works for both.
